Award.AwardTitle: MEMS Device for Molecular Sorting and Pumping with Moving Boundaries

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
MEMS Device for Molecular Sorting and Pumping with Moving Boundaries


The objective of this research is to design, fabricate, and optimize an active MEMS device for microfluidic pumping and molecular sorting. The approach is to use cascaded moving boundaries coupled with a specific geometric design of nozzle and diffuser elements to create a highly efficient unidirectional flow. For filtering, a surface acoustic wave generator will be integrated in the device to actively modulate the transport and surface adhesion of specific compounds. Microfabrication of the device will be performed using polydimethylsiloxane polymer, electrostatic actuation, and piezoelectric technology, based on computational simulations of the design. The prototype device will be used to validate the initial numerical design and the computational model will then be used to further optimize the device.
Intellectual Merit: The proposed research will contribute to basic developments through coupled fluid-structure simulations and prototype fabrication in the design and synthesis of MEMS devices with moving boundaries for effective pumping and molecular sorting. The proposed device will significantly improve existing technology by creating unidirectional flow from a microfluidic moving boundary system. This research will extend the current state-of-the-art in the areas of computational simulations, MEMS device design and fabrication, and optimization.
Broader Impacts: Development of a MEMS device aided by computational simulations will lead to the design of micro-/nanoscale systems for on-chip biological fluid diagnostic systems, targeted drug delivery, and immunoisolation of bio-artificial organs. Lab-on-a-chip systems that will benefit from this work will ultimately provide inexpensive and fast laboratory diagnostic and assessment tools to medical, environmental, and military personnel in clinical settings or in remote, rural, and poorly served locations. Graduate and undergraduate students involved in this research will acquire multidisciplinary training in the fields of computational modeling, micro-device fabrication, and biological applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Goals: In this project, a MEMS device concept with cascaded moving boundaries was developed for multiple applications for fluid pumping and molecule sorting. We conducted design simulations with CFD, and completed fluid-structure interactions, design optimization, silicon fabrication and replica prototyping procedures in developing and demonstrating the developed microdevice. The results, findings, accomplishments, and innovations resulting from the project are briefly described below.

 

Results: A new micropump was designed and fabricated for transporting liquids using three nozzle/diffuser elements with top actuation. The specified actuation is achieved by a reciprocal motor actuator and can be accurately controlled through an externally supplied voltage. Based on the performance studies conducted, the designed micropump performs reasonably well. A design optimization procedure based on coupled solid–fluid analysis was used to achieve a specific flow rate through the micropump. Genetic algorithms along with artificial neural networks were used for optimizing the pump geometry and actuation frequency. Three optimized geometries resulted in flow rates which matched the predicted flow rates with 95% accuracy. These geometries need further investigation to address fabrication and manufacturing issues. The performance of a valveless micropump driven by two actuation mechanisms was evaluated. The performance characteristics of flow rate and energy/power consumption were obtained from computational simulations and demonstrate the efficiency of the two actuation mechanisms (side wall and top actuations) in the micropump.  The results obtained illustrate the relationship between actuation frequency, fluid flow, and energy consumption through the micropump. Based on the performance evaluation of the two actuations, side actuation is superior to top/bottom actuation in terms of power consumption.

 

We also developed a novel micropump droplet generator based on a microfluidics device to produce monodisperse droplets on demand for aerosol drug delivery applications. The micropump design was employed to both pump the fluid into the air and to encourage droplet breakup and aerosol formation.  Computational simulations demonstrated that the present droplet generator performed effectively at higher frequencies, and smaller nozzle diameters regardless of the liquid viscosity of the solution. We also explored the device for molecule/particle sorting applications as well.

 

Findings: A valveless micropump with multiple vibrating membranes was successfully used to achieve a unidirectional flow. The computational simulation results showed that the maximum membrane displacement, membrane frequency, and pressure head were major factors affecting the maximum instantaneous flow rate and the average flow rate of the novel micropump. The maximum instantaneous flow rate and the average flow rate increased when the maximum membrane displacement and frequency increased. However, the maximum instantaneous flow rate and the average flow rate decreased when pressure head increased. Increases in maximum pressure head were associated with increases in membrane frequency. Using the proposed design, retrograde flow was eliminated for most conditions that were considered. A valveless micropump design concept with novel actuation to transport drug particles for biomedical applications was also developed.
